headline.main-hed: Latest ‘Hunger Games’ Film Opens to $123 Million

alt-summary-body.p: The latest installment of “The Hunger Games” film series, “Mockingjay Part 1,” sold $123 million of tickets in its debut weekend, easily making it the biggest opening of 2014, but the box-office take was 22% lower than the prior “Hunger Games” movie.

“The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1” sold $123 million of tickets in its debut weekend, easily making it the biggest opening of 2014, but the box-office take was 22% lower than the prior movie in the series.

headline.main-hed: The latest “Hunger Games” was a hit by nearly any measure—except its own
Latest ‘Hunger Games’ Ticket Sales Miss Target

summary-body.p: “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1” sold $123 million of tickets in its debut weekend, easily making it the biggest opening of 2014, but the box-office take was 22% lower than the prior movie in the series.

headline.main-hed: Latest ‘Hunger Games’ Film Opens to $123 Million
headline.deck: Biggest Opening of 2014 Falls Behind Previous Installments

media.media-caption: ‘The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Part 1’ took in $123 million domestically this weekend, easily making it the biggest opening in 2014.

article-body.p: The latest installment of “The Hunger Games” film series was a hit by nearly any measure—except its own.

“The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1” opened to $123 million in the U.S. and Canada, according to an estimate from studio Lions Gate Entertainment Corp. Although that is easily the biggest opening of 2014, it is 22% lower than the prior “Hunger Games” movie, “Catching Fire,” which opened to $158.1 million on the same weekend last year. The first “Hunger Games” opened to $152.5 million in March 2012.

Investors dinged Lions Gate’s stock after it became apparent from screenings late Thursday that “Mockingjay” likely wouldn’t perform as well as its predecessors. Shares in the studio dropped 5% on Friday, settling at $33.25 in 4 p.m. trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The blockbuster performances of “The Hunger Games,” starring Jennifer Lawrence and based on a best-selling young-adult trilogy, have been a key driver of a roughly threefold increase in Lions Gate’s stock price since early 2012. Though the company also has a growing television unit that makes “Mad Men” and “Orange is the New Black,” motion pictures are its biggest business and “The Hunger Games” its most valuable asset. The last two movies grossed a total of $1.56 billion world-wide.

As Hollywood studios have become more reliant on mega-franchises, they also are more sensitive to any signs of diminishing interest. This past summer, for instance, the latest “Transformers” and “Amazing Spider-Man” both performed worse than preceding films domestically, despite collecting an impressive $1.1 billion and $709 million world-wide, respectively. As a result, the studios behind them are carefully pondering their next steps rather than rushing ahead with another sequel.
The U.S. market remains the most important in the world because it ultimately accounts for the most profits after a film is released in theaters, on DVD and on television and digital platforms.

There are a few possible reasons for the underperformance of “Mockingjay Part 1.” They include weaker reviews than the prior “Hunger Games” movies and an overall softness at the box office this year. Some have also questioned whether the third and final “Hunger Games” book has enough substance to merit being split into two parts on the big screen—a strategy Lions Gate label Summit Entertainment previously used successfully with “Twilight” and Warner Bros. used with “Harry Potter.”

With a production budget of about $140 million, the movie is still certain to be quite profitable. And compared with last year, when the hugely successful “Frozen” opened five days after “Catching Fire,” competition is lighter in the coming weeks.

“This is the biggest opening of the year and we’re in November, so that’s impressive,” said David Spitz, Lions Gate’s executive vice president of distribution. “The last time a movie could say that is ‘Catching Fire’ and that speaks volumes about the franchise.”
Malaise wasn’t evident overseas, where “Mockingjay” opened to an estimated $152 million, surpassing “Catching Fire” by 4% in the same markets, according to Lions Gate.

Because it has distribution operations only in the U.S., Canada and U.K., Lions Gate licensed rights to release the film to other companies in most foreign countries. It collected about $120 million from such “pre-sales,” according to a knowledgeable person. Those deals help to limit risk, but also reduce profits if the movie outperforms expectations internationally.
Write to Ben Fritz at ben.fritz@wsj.com
